ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Online book learning and assignments, assignments and brief lessons through Canvas

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Improved writing and fluency in Spanish.
I got better at recognizing and using different forms and conjugations of Spanish in my writing

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It is a little hard to know what other ways you can study and prepare for the tests. Especially since my teacher was not the coordinator of the class.

Weakness is that my speaking definitely did not improve, but it was different because it was over zoom. In person I have always been forced to speak and figure it out, over Zoom not so much. Having to read the novel did help with reading.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course director had no clue how to use virtual resources.
Spanish is definitely one of those classes that can be taught via zoom so I think everything worked out well.

The online book practice was a success, I actually enjoyed the extra practice because many times I would skip the lesson in the book but the daily assignments forced me to learn the material. The Zoom seminar was hard for me because I am a terrible Spanish speaker, and I feel I did not improve over the semester with my speaking. In person I am forced to figure it out, over Zoom I was able to shy away and not speak as much.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, but it is alot of busy work because that is the only way you get better at a language.

Online, yes. In person, probably not. Taking a language, especially a hard Spanish course is going to be much more difficult in person, so I would recommend taking something like Indonesian. It is ridiculous and very scary how heavy the weight is for language classes at Yale, so my advice would be to take an easy class and secure an A.
